security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based documentation skill containing only API design guidelines. No executable code, no network access, no file system access, no external commands. This skill provides documentation for Java Spring Boot developers and presents no security risk.

content.user_title: Design REST APIs with Allra standards
content.value_statement: This skill provides standardized API design guidelines for Java Spring Boot developers. It defines consistent package structures, DTO naming conventions, and REST endpoint patterns to ensure uniformity across backend projects.
actual_capabilities: Define domain-driven package structures with api, dto, entity, repository, and service layers
Apply consistent DTO naming conventions for request, response, and internal DTOs
Create RESTful API endpoints following standard HTTP method conventions
Implement Bean Validation on request DTOs with proper annotations
Use Java records for simple DTO classes
Structure error responses with standardized error codes and messages
limitations: Focused specifically on Java Spring Boot projects only
Does not generate actual code implementations
Assumes familiarity with Java and Spring Boot fundamentals
Does not cover database-specific optimizations or query performance

prompt_templates.title: Create New API
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new REST API endpoint for user registration following Allra API Design standards. Include package structure, request/response DTOs, controller, and service layer.

prompt_templates.title: Design DTOs
prompt_templates.prompt: Design appropriate DTOs for a product management API following Allra conventions. Include request DTOs, response DTOs, and internal event DTOs using Java records.

prompt_templates.title: Review API Structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my current API package structure and suggest improvements based on Allra API Design standards. Check DTO naming, layer separation, and REST conventions.

prompt_templates.title: Error Handling
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a standardized error response structure for my Spring Boot API following Allra conventions, including error codes, messages, and details field.

output_examples.input: Create a user login API endpoint with email and password validation
output: LoginRequest uses record with @NotBlank @Email validation on email field
LoginResponse returns userId and accessToken on successful authentication
Controller maps POST /api/v1/users/login with proper error handling

best_practices: Use domain-driven package structures with clear layer separation between api, dto, entity, repository, and service
Prefer Java records over classes for simple DTOs to reduce boilerplate code
Apply consistent naming: OperationRequest, OperationResponse, and internal OperationDto suffixes
anti_patterns: Mixing request and response DTOs in the same class instead of separating them
Using generic names like UserDTO instead of specific names like UserSignUpRequest
Skipping Bean Validation on request DTOs, leading to unvalidated input reaching services

faq.question: Which Java and Spring Boot versions are supported?
faq.answer: This skill targets Java 17+ and Spring Boot 3.2+ with support for JPA/Hibernate, QueryDSL, and JWT.

faq.question: Can this skill generate complete working code?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides design guidelines and patterns. You will need to implement the actual business logic in service layers.

faq.question: Does this work with frameworks other than Spring Boot?
faq.answer: The standards are specifically designed for Spring Boot. Other frameworks like Quarkus or Micronaut may require adjustments.

faq.question: Is my project data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No, this is a pure prompt skill. No code executes and no data leaves your environment during usage.
